title: 113_hr5394
content: The Act may be cited as the "Department of Education Elimination Act of 2014". Congress finds that the Department of Education is inconsistent with the principles of federalism, undermines parental decision-making, and weakens community governance of schools. The Department of Education has seen a significant increase in funding, reaching almost $65.7 billion annually, but education performance for 17-year olds has remained stagnant since 1971. The Department is criticized for over-regulation, high overhead costs, and poor test results in mathematics, science, and reading compared to other nations. Initiatives led by parents and local communities are crucial to improving educational performance in the United States. The current top-down education system is harmful to local businesses, communities, and the nation's global competitiveness. The Department of Education is resistant to reform ideas that empower parents, teachers, and local communities, leading to standardized education that neglects the diverse needs of students. The Department of Education is abolished, along with programs under its administrative responsibility. Grants to states for education programs are established. Each State is entitled to receive grants from the Secretary of the Treasury for elementary, secondary, and postsecondary education programs, based on funds appropriated in fiscal year 2012. Each State receives grants from the Treasury for education programs based on funds appropriated in fiscal year 2012. Funds are allocated for fiscal years 2015 through 2024, with requirements for direct transfer to States and expenditure within specified timeframes. The State must use grants for education purposes allowed by State law, either for elementary/secondary education or postsecondary education. The grants should supplement, not replace, funds from non-Federal sources for education programs. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATIVE AND FISCAL ACCOUNTABILITY. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATIVE AND FISCAL ACCOUNTABILITY. (a) Audits.-- A State must contract with an approved auditing entity annually to conduct an audit of expenditures made from grant funds to ensure compliance with section 4. The audit of State expenditures must be conducted annually by an approved auditing entity in accordance with auditing principles. The entity must be approved by the Secretary of the Treasury, the State's chief executive officer, and be independent of any government agency. The audit results must be submitted by April 30, 2016, and annually thereafter. The approved auditing entity must conduct an annual audit of State expenditures, reporting violations to the State legislature and the Secretary of the Treasury. States found in violation of specific requirements must reimburse the Treasury and face penalties. Annual reporting to the Secretary of the Treasury and State legislature is mandatory. The State must submit an annual report to the Treasury and State legislature detailing activities funded by grants received under section 4. The report must include audit results, grant amount, and additional necessary information determined by the State. The State must provide an accurate description of activities conducted and a record of expenditures for grants received under section 4. Reports must be made publicly available on a website and in other formats upon request. Failure to submit required audits may result in the withholding of grant payments by the Treasury Secretary. The State must submit audits on time, failure to do so may result in grant payment withholding. The Secretary of the Treasury has limited authority under the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury has authority to implement rules, make payments to States, approve entities for audits, withhold or offset grant payments to States, and enforce nondiscrimination rules under the Act. The Attorney General's authority to supervise state funds received under section 4 is limited to section 6(b). States retain the power to pursue penalties against those who misuse or commit fraud related to the funds provided under section 4. SEC. 6. NONDISCRIMINATION PROVISIONS. SEC. 6. NONDISCRIMINATION PROVISIONS. No individual shall be excluded from participation in, denied benefits, or discriminated against in programs funded with state amounts based on disability, sex, race, color, or national origin. Compliance is required, and failure to comply may result in actions by the Attorney General. The Secretary of the Treasury shall notify the State's chief executive officer of any failure to comply with nondiscrimination provisions. If compliance is not secured within 60 days, the Attorney General may take legal action under various civil rights laws. The Secretary of the Treasury notifies the State's chief executive officer of any noncompliance with nondiscrimination provisions, with the Attorney General authorized to take legal action if compliance is not achieved within 60 days. The Civil Rights Act of 1964 may be applicable in such cases. SEC. 7. TRANSFER OF CERTAIN DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION PROGRAMS. Within 24 months of this Act, job training programs under the Department of Education, special education grant programs under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, Indian Education programs, and Impact Aid programs will be transferred to the Department of Labor, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of the Interior, and Department of Defense respectively. The Federal Pell Grant program and Federal student loan programs will be transferred to the Department of Defense and Department of Health and Human Services respectively, with a cap of $18 billion per fiscal year. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment to evaluate reducing the Federal tax burden for education funding. Additionally, the feasibility of successor Federal agencies maintaining transferred programs will be assessed. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, the President must present a plan to Congress for winding up the Department of Education. Definitions for terms like elementary school, secondary school, institution of higher education, and State are provided in the Act.
